newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cambodian opposition leader challenges Hun Sen.
newsitem.headline: Cambodian opposition leader challenges Hun Sen.

text.p: A Cambodian opposition leader on Saturday accused Second Prime Minister Hun Sen of ordering a bloody grenade attack on an opposition rally in Phnom Penh and challenged him to refute the charge in a justice system outside Cambodia.

"In publicly accusing Hun Sen, from France, of having ordered the criminal attack of March 30, 1997, I challenge him to file suit against me for slander in a French court," Sam Rainsy, leader of the Khmer Nation Party (KNP), told Reuters.
"I wish to confront him in an independent and impartial justice system, which does not exist in Cambodia," Rainsy said.
Hun Sen has previously declined comment on suggestions by Rainsy that he was linked to the attack.

The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation has been assisting Cambodian authorities in their investigation of the grenade attack on a demonstration led by Rainsy which left up to 19 dead and more than 100 wounded.
Rainsy, who narrowly escaped injury in the attack, is a political ally of First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh and the main political rival of Hun Sen.
Ranariddh and Hun Sen have been waging a bitter war of words in recent months over various disagreements including power-sharing in their coalition government.
Rainsy told Reuters in a telephone interview that he had documentary evidence proving that Hun Sen had ordered the attack.
But he said he would only make the evidence public in front of an independent judge, such as one in France.
He said a slander complaint against him would oblige the French authorities to investigate the incident.
